displayed_text:
Family Member: He’s at M___ because I worked there. Doctor: That used to be C____> Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Mm,hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Will you make your own appointment with him? Family Member: I can. I mean whatever I need to do, just let me know. I’ll do it. (pause) Doctor: Yeah um. Do you want to talk to him soon?
FAM Probably. I know you don’t necessarily start soon. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: In terms of getting hormone therapy do you want to do it with us? He could do it too. Family Member: Oh, well, he only has to come in how often for that? Doctor: The most common way is once every three months. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Well okay so you’re talking three different options. Doctor: Yeah basically. Patient: Which one, which one I guess was your recommendation? Doctor: What I was going to propose is that we do things in parallel. Okay? I was going to sort of leave the chemotherapy as a last possible option only because you have it available at any time. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: You know we can go to it if none of these work or even after they work and then stop working after sometime. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And who knows what we may have by then too. If you don’t need it at all at that time. The, the I was going to sugg-propose that we do the prescreening and the blood test in anticipation of doing that testing for your blood today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that way we have at least that cooking… Family Member: Check the markers and? Doctor: Right. If the markers are positive, I think you should go on the Niraparib, the PARP inhibitor - the targeted treatment…

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s been tried; even the addition of chemotherapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yet it prolongs the recurrence, but it still doesn’t prevent the recurrence or prevent it recurring. Healthcare Professional: But then there’s therapies that happen. Doctor: Right. That’s one of the last options Healthcare Professional: Yeah, yeah, there are other therapies for when that happens. Family Member: Aside from hormones. Healthcare Professional: So they stay on the hormones. Family Member: Oh. Healthcare Professional: So he stays on the hormones but then we add to it. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Either a second-line hormone like he was talking about that they’re looking at this trial using it earlier.

Patient: Two months, two weeks, yeah. Doctor: Was at zero point five. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay, so that’s very good news because it’s a very slight - Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it was zero point three. The time before that it was like two months before and went from point three to point five. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay and I did mention to you that your testosterone is also going up. Patient: Right. Doctor: However, I think given the fact that you’re feeling relatively well. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Except for that slight increase in fatigue, perhaps, and given that the PSA level is still very low, and I can’t imagine that a PSA of zero point five comes high to you or your body or you know increase the risk of this prostate cancer causing you know either side effects or um you know even death because it’s still quite low. Patient: Uh huh.

Family Member: Okay. (sighs) Doctor: No. It’ll be back by tomorrow. Family Member: Okay. And that won’t change the course of what you recommend anyway? Doctor: It’s either gonna be zero or like point one or two so um. Family Member: What if it’s not though? What if it hasn’t gone down that much? Does that lead us to believe…? Doctor: It’s still not gonna change what we’re gonna do. Patient: Right. Family Member: Does that lead you to believe there’s more there still if it’s higher? Doctor: Yeah then one would think it’s in another part of your body like in the bones or something like that. Family Member: Um hum, um hum. That’s what I worry about too. Doctor: Um the question arose about getting scans on you? Patient: Mm, hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Mm,hmm.

Patient: Is that just starting? Doctor: Uh, that has been open probably for a couple of months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it has a lot of rules. Either, you have to be AR-V7 positive. So, we would have to draw a tube of blood. Uh, and that we can do. Uh, it takes a week to come back. If you scream positive with that as positive, then the team could talk to you about the study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. If you’re negative, then you’re not eligible from the get-go. Patient: Right. Doctor: Because you have to be positive to go onto that study. The other two studies, it doesn’t matter about what your AR-V7. AR-V7 gives us a sense of what’s the likelihood that Enzalutamide’s gonna work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What’s the likelihood that Abiraterone’s gonna work. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um. In this case, we’re trying to just sort out men who, um, have an AR-V7 positive as a bad thing. Uh. So, that says that we’re willing to go with immune therapy which hasn’t been proven at a high risk/high gain, uh, thing in that kind of individual.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: go running off somewhere. Okay, that sounds good Dr. H____, let’s do it. Patient: I mean that works for me. Doctor: Ok, that’s it. Patient: I mean since I got to come here anyway. Doctor: Yes and honestly I think your pain sometimes gets worse because you’re anemic Patient: Yeah, I mean it’s Doctor: so we got to fix that. Patient: it’s got to be worse since the last time I got that prescription from you. Doctor: Correct. Patient: It wasn’t as bad as it is now. Doctor: Right. Patient: Because I get to the bottom of the prescription it’s like…

Family Member 3: So um, we are worried about him being around the mother that is newly pregnant, she gets her first ultrasound right now. So what do you think? Doctor: Well, they're, you know- Family Member 1: If they ask us for dinner. Doctor: Yeah, I mean, it's sort of you know, you're you're just having social contact is okay. Family Member 1: It’s okay. So he could be around them. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Family Member 2: Okay, so you're going to look into the Restiril possibly. Doctor: He's got sleep issues, so we'll have to see the Restiril and drug interactions, Healthcare Professional: yeah, there's a lot of drug interactions. Doctor: Yeah I remember. Healthcare Professional: There’s a full list.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So again, you’ve got the multiple sites of cancer in your bones, and you’ve got swollen glands down in your pelvis, don’t look like they’re from your cancer. Huh, let me see what I told you last time so that I am consistent. Okay. So what questions do you have for me? Patient: Huh, only one, I mean, huh, what are we going to do about this pain I’m feeling? Are we going to do what we’re doing? What we’ve been doing? Doctor: Yeah. I, I’m, I’m thinking we need to change. Huh, you know, get you off these pills and maybe go to chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, chemotherapy’s got about a one in two chance of helping the pain. Huh, we could always radiate your bones if the pain doesn’t get better with the chemo. Huh, but I’d like to give you something that goes everywhere the cancer cells are, huh, so that, huh, huh, it’s a different approach than what we’ve done. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Huh, so normally what you would end up doing is stopping the four pills. You can stop that. The prednisone you would stay on because we need it for the chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I think last time we talked a little bit about we have one clinical trial where we are giving men chemotherapy. Huh, that’s the standard. Huh, and then we, huh, ask men to participate and also getting vitamin C. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That’s the experimental part. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay, alright, so let me check with D__ if your PSA came back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We are going to do one last ditch effort. I don’t know what’s taking so long even for the labs today. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah, yeah, okay. Doctor: I think after the weekend everyone’s waking up slowly. Patient: My wife just went down… Doctor: Yeah I met her. Patient: Okay did ya? Doctor: She said well yeah just start talking to the two of you.

Patient: - going down and coming back, and, uh, my daughter said you don’t seem like you feel anything. I said, no, I feel pretty good there. And, uh, so I do have those particular days, but then I have those days as well. I said, oh, man, when this day going to be over with so I can go to bed tonight Doctor: Is that because of pain that those days are hard for you? Patient: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work. Doctor: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-? Patient: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night. Doctor: So you’re waking up because of pain? Patient: Uh, not pain all the time. Sometimes it’s just, uh, what’s the term I’m looking for? Doctor: Discomfort? Patient: Yeah. You know? And, uh, just trying to get in a place where you feel like this is where I need to be at, I’m happy here. So, uh, uh, one of the best sleeping place, and I hate to say it, is my living room downstairs on the couch. I prop the pillows up, and, uh, and got my favorite space, so when I lay down and put my back up right up against the back of it, but I don’t want to be in the business of sleeping on my living room couch every night, either. We have a sleep number bed that we purchased just for this, but, uh, uh, I wouldn’t recommend sleep number being if that’s what you’re going, you’re going to use it for, because it’s not all it’s, it’s cut out to be. You’re paying a lot of money for a bed. And sometimes it works, sometimes it don’t. So my biggest challenge each night is to figure out, okay, what’s going to work tonight? Is my Lazy Boy going to work? Uh, I even tried the floor with my granddaughter’s, uh, what do you call those things she has? Family Member: The bean bag. Patient: The bean bags. That was the worst idea I ever had. When I got in that bean bag, uh, I, I was in pain. And the bad part is I couldn’t get back out of the, get out of the bean bag, and get off the floor.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Some other race: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Some other race

displayed_text: Patient: Yep. Doctor: And let me see if you’re all set for when your next hormone shot is. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that’s due the last week of, first week of, last week of April. And you’re set for that. You already have that appointment set up, add on because it will be three weeks from now about when we might get started with the chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? I refilled the ibuprofen. I sent it to your local pharmacy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you’re set there. And there’s probably nobody out there right now. Patient: Right. Doctor: I always end up with you late in the day. Doctor: At least you don’t have to go to the ER tonight. Patient: Right. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? So then I’ll let you head out and, huh, we’ll check on whether the trial makes sense. So I’ll say, read the consents, we will review your records to see if eligible, because if you need blood, I can give you a blood transfusion, but the hep C we may not be able to.

Patient: Tomorrow I’ll be eating at the shop. Doctor: Alright let’s see. Patient: And today. Patient: Yep I’ll be down there Wednesday. I think Wednesday they’re doing a what-ya-call-it on the similar… Doctor: Okay now you have a higher dose of OxyContin than the Percocet. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So with the Percocet you’re actually going lower on the dose of the OxyContin. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’re okay with that? Patient: Okay. What you think? Doctor: Well I don’t think it’s going to be all that much better for you, but if you think so I’m willing to give it a try instead of the Norco. Patient: Okay well I’m with you.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s in a location which is classical and typical for where prostate cancer can typically spread. Patient: Okay then that’s - where is it? Where did you say it went? Doctor: I have to remind myself which side it’s on. It’s on the abdominal - it’s in the abdomen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s too deep to feel, so it’s internal, inside the abdomen. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s on the uh - it’s called the left iliac lymph node. So the left iliac lymph node is basically um where the blood vessel called the aorta splits up into the two iliac arteries. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then there are lymph nodes on each side. So I would say if I, if I could go through your abdomen like three inches, I’d hit it; it’s on the left side. Patient: Now I did have uh a gist and I had that surgery July the thirteenth. I remember that was in the stomach. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So is it in somewhere in comparison…? Well I guess they’re two independent things then.

Healthcare Professional: Yeah. That place is really nice. Doctor: Yeah. But I think the nice part with that is they you know people running out Patient: Yeah. Doctor: at Hopkins know Patient: Yeah. Doctor: this is a toll on people coming up every week. Patient: Yeah. Well, I, you know, I, I totally live, chemo would be logistically a problem. You know? I mean I’m, you know, I kind of dread it. I do. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I kind of knew it was coming but uh. What do you think the duration of that? Doctor: Of the treatment? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So on a trial, it’s for eight treatments.
